Brian Egendorf | June 15, 2011 11:22 AM

On one hand, I think 3D glasses have to be designed to be more comfortable..BUT wearing them doesn't really bother me. I don't really get why it bothers others. If i had my druthers, I'd like to see custom made 3D glasses that are designed for your eyes specifically, and with a slight magnification to bring the screen itself closer to the viewer. I find it more distracting when I can still see screen edges within my viewing field of the glasses.

Another suggestion to most movie theaters is paint your ceiling non-reflective matte black for the first 1/4 of the theater from the screen. Reflections from the screen to the ceiling are picked up at the bottom of the glasses as random light/movement.. Thats a little distracting.

When it is done well, I like 3D. Someone was talking about depth of field, and how a narrow depth of field, and infinite depth of field are equally distracting in a 3D film. I agree with the narrow depth of field..but when I can see the entire background that isn't blurred out, I feel like I am THERE. I feel more like I am witnessing the movie in person as opposed to just watching it from a seat. Newsflash..if you can't focus cause everything is in focus..you have ADD. Don't deny me visually drinking in the whole scene cause YOU can't concentrate on it.

Although, I have stated in the past that slowing up certain scenes or segments of action allows you to take them in and appreciate them more then lettting them play in real time. This is even more true in 3D.

I can tell you that the problem isn't that people aren't interested in 3D Televisions. Its that people can't afford 3D televisions right now. The market sucks in general right now, and a lot of new technologies are experiencing a tough time being sold in this economy.

That being said..if you already have a high def television, don't bother to sell it and go get a 3D one..Get a 3D converter box instead. You'll save a lot of money, and they are more configurable and portable, and you don't need a 3D Blu-Ray player to use it, so you'll save even more money. And unlike some TV's which don't take standard or digital or HD TV signal to 3D, the box will.

Jim Piechocki | July 8, 2011 6:36 AM

Murch's rant against 3D has a simple, self-serving basis: 3D puts him out of business as an editor. I took a sound design class from him at USC Film School in which he announced that fast-paced editing - such as the Flight of the Valkyrie helicopter set piece in APOCALYPSE NOW - would wipe out traditional editing. Now he faces a similar paradigm shift. To create convergence without headaches, 3D requires slowing cinema down to HALF as many cuts as 2D films. Murch's 67 year-old brain is having a hard time wrapping itself around the concept. So, too, do many young minds: editors and directors who have been trained to mask bad design behind fast-paced editing that APOCALYPSE and MTV have spawned. In recent weeks, TRANSFORMERS 3D has created another shakeup by proving that competent 3D is worth billions in effective entertainment. 3D may not be welcome by the old guard, but it is here to stay.

Classifieds | July 8, 2011 12:10 PM

hah! i agree... but now more and movies are coming out in 3d... what to do.

mirek krejci | July 12, 2011 10:20 PM

Walter nails it thats why i prefer a good book to stereo. But tell that to these 20 year old FX freaks in post houses and you will start the next war

Philip A. Femano | July 19, 2011 4:18 PM

If Murch had been trained in neuroscience he would realize his description of how the brain reacts to a stereoscopic image is incorrect. As Murch correctly states, when presented with a stereo image the brain must do two things: 1) adjust its parallax conversion, and 2) focus the image on the retina. But where Murch falls short is his description of the process of focusing. He implies that the brain will automatically focus to a shorter distance when the interoccular angle decreases, and this conflicts with what is required to focus on a stereoscopic movie. However, the brain's reflex circuitry for interoccular angle is not the same as the circuitry for focusing. The brain's focusing mechanism is strictly determined by the edge detection, not interocular angle. That is, the visual circuitry in the brain simply endeavors to make the target image -- eg, that which hits the fovea -- as "sharp" as possible. In fact, even when you're staring at the same object for a length of time, the brain still makes miniscule adjustments to over- and under-focus just to be sure it's always right in focus. It's the same as driving a car: on a perfectly straight road, you still make small left/right corrections all along the way to ensure you stay on the road.   

On the other hand, people do get headaches when the stereo presentation is technologically flawed. This happened very often during film presentations at 24 fps where not only was the flicker paralyzing at such low frame rates, but the horizontal parallax was often distorted (eg, due to bad cinematographic technique, or maladjusted dual-projector setup), and the two images were at different levels VERTICALLY (the latter being extremely challenging for the normal brain to converge on). People do NOT get headaches when the parallax is "natural" (eg., not wider than parallel when the object is at infinity, not so close that your eyes have to angle in on the bridge of your nose, and with the left/right frames on a perfect horizontal). Also, the strobing effect has become extremely minimized with progressive scan at 120 fps.   

And so when you consider how the brain actually focuses, today's stereoscopic video technology is actually EASIER on the brain, not tougher, and so you get FEWER headaches than you do in the real 3D world by virtue of the fact that your muscles which are responsible for focusing actually have very little work to do since everything in the image is on the same plane. If Murch gets headaches, it's either because he needs a new eyeglass prescription, or because he's used to editing from a screen where there is no need for dynamic horizontal parallax conversion. It's not the focusing that gives him the headaches. Instead, his problem is that his eyes need to impose a new physical activity (dynamic parallax conversion) which is something that a 2D film editor never has to deal with. Just like any new exercise, he's using muscles he's never used before in his day job!

BOTTOM LINE: Murch won all of his awards on 2D video and it is on that terrain he should remain. Sorry Walter, but it's time for you railroad engineers to make room for the jet pilots.

LP | July 22, 2011 8:48 AM

I'm not sure I buy the argument. 600 million years didn't prepare us to fly, or go to the moon, or realize that the sounds coming out of cell phones with no human being present are someone's voice... but we do it. What 600 million years prepared us to do is adapt.

People are going to get used to seeing images in 3D -- the technology exists and it ISN'T going away. It's going to be improved upon and innovated. Eventually people will grow up with it and come to expect it, just as people my age find black and white, monaural, adequate but deficient.

I remember seeing Bolt!, the animated feature in which John Travolta voices a dog, in 3D. Trivial, I know. But the scene in which the characters were trapped in a burning building was a revelation to me. The sensation of what it was like to be trapped in a narrow pocket of air under a billowing layer of toxic smoke was brought home to me by the 3D process in a visceral way unlike anything my own imagination had ever conjured. That alone sold me on the value of the new technology.

No, I don't want to go back. I want to see what they can show me next. If you don't like it, shut one eye. ;)

Charles Murray | July 26, 2011 11:06 AM

Roger and Mr, Murch, I have been struggling for a while to come to terms with 3D. The reality is, after having seen a goodly number of 3D films, I now actively take measures to avoid seeing them. It’s not the extra $3, it’s the fact I just don’t seem to enjoy 3D movies as much. Now I know why.

It seems to me as if the experience, even when it works as a kind of thrill-ride trick, keeps pushing me out of the more immersive experience of the film and its plot. Now I suspect this is happening on a subtle level even when I don't notice it consciously.

There is more 3D on the credits than the movies. I have watched 2 3D movies in the past and not planning to do it again.

Duncan replied to comment from LP | August 1, 2011 4:13 PM

But flying doesn't require anything special from our cognitive systems; you sit on a chair and try not to think about crashing. When it does (when /you're/ actually flying a plane) people to experience problems; I'm sure everyone's heard about the issue of course correcting when in cloud cover or performing multiple-G maneuvers when one is actually flying a plane; the brain doesn't adapt itself very well to these situations). Take a more mundane example; boats. We didn't evolve to use boats. 'Fine' you say 'but we can use boats just fine'. Au contraire; when the brain visually detects the motion of its surroundings which differs from the motion it detects through the balance system in the ears it assumes something toxic has been ingested and induces vomiting; this is, of course, sea sickness and is roughly analoguous to the kind of problem described above: 3D asks the visual system to do things which it is sub-optimised for doing (because it never has to, in real life). It /might/ be possible that if you locked yourself in a cinema for the rest of your life and watched nothing but 3D films neural plasticity is such that you'd eventually adapt to perform this feat quite easily, but we can assume that most people are not going to do that so 3D cinema remains, like Communism, an interesting idea which is sadly ill-suited for human beings as they are.

JC | August 5, 2011 4:22 PM

I agree with Walters technical perspective. However we have to look outside the box. Film, TV, etc only serves as entertainment. What you find entertaining and I find entertaining and are both willing to pay for are 2 completely different choices. If someone likes the 3D and is willing to pay for it, well why not?
It made Avatar a nice chunk of $$$.

2nd) Let's think about this. How much more jobs, business, employment, etc has this 3D craze brought to our field?
thousands of $$? millions of $$$? or BILLIONS of $$$$$$$
I am talking about all the jobs and technical achievements brought about from 3D glasses, 3D Blu Ray players, 3D TV/LCD/Rear Projectors/Screens/Theaters, software, hardware, more people are now employed to make and design software & hwardware to edit and create and advance 3D content. Millions of people are buying into it, millions are spending $$$ all accross the board.

3rd) Let's be honest here, film was taking a HUGE slump at the box office, now with this 3D technology, more and more people are going to see movies. Which means more studios are willing to take the risk, meaning more employment for us editors.

I hope it stays and something else comes out in 5-7 years to replace it so more and more people are reeled in to the theaters, to buy Blu rays, buy content and equipment, since in the end, it stimulates our economy and those who like it, get more out of enjoying entertainment.

Hope I am not the only one who can appreciate this.

JD | August 9, 2011 10:29 AM

Wow... have you ever even seen a 3D movie? Seeing is believing. 3D is the future. Eye convergence and parallax issues are a non-issue at the depths shown in theaters (public ones or home). Your eyes adjust to the relative depth in just a few minutes just as they will white balance. You could make the exact same argument about the fact that billions of years of evolution have not taught us to view what is really a 3D scene on a 2D screen. It's all about immersion. 3D is not perfect but it does add a level of detail that is not possible on a 2D screen. Deal with it, and deal with the fact that you may have to learn/adapt to new technologies. Your ignorance regarding 3D motion pictures is akin to the people who refused to give up records when CD's first came out.

Paulo | August 11, 2011 5:24 PM

I think the numbers and the success of 3D movies speak against Mr. Murch. Most blockbusters this years are in 3D... and I suspect next year all of them will be in 3D. And two years after that, how many indie films will be in 3D? A lot of them, I suspect.

Everything Mr. Murch says about 3D could be said about multichannel audio: it's too loud and it comes from impossible places in relation to the screen. But there it is.

I'm afraid Mr. Murch is too dogmatic, too stuck with the old 3D films (while the technology today is much sophisticated) and... maybe he is too old and his eyes hurt.

Regardless, audiences keep on going to 3D movies and I haven't heards complaints about the experience. What Mr. Murch doesn't seem to get is that 3D is now a creative tool just like color, sound and so many others. It can be used well or it can be used poorly.

But this is true for most anything.

Matthew | August 17, 2011 7:34 AM

In response to Paulo:

Numbers and success do not speak against Mr. Murch, rather they speak for the marketing departments of major corporations and the power of unconscious peer pressure to follow the crowd.

That blockbusters (or Major Studio) films are released in 3D says nothing for the format itself, only that the parent corporations see the current economic benefit.

You may suspect 'all of them will be in 3D next year' but we will have to wait and see. I doubt it. Corporate revenue driving the decision making process has never worked out for industry. Very soon, I'm sure we'll see true indies take advantage of the major studios oversight, get rid of the gimmicks and get back to emotional/story based cinema.

Prequels, sequals, adaptations and remakes. How un-original can the majors be (putting all gimmicks and psychological marking aside).

"Everything Mr. Murch says about 3D could be said about multichannel audio."

Well, it can't be 'dark', it's not 'small', it's certainly not 'stroby', 'headache inducing', 'expensive' and I don't recall a time when ticket prices were increased for multi-channel audio. Alienating could be argued, but even then, the way it's used by the experts never brings your consciousness out of the screen (the 2D screen that is). And as far as 'multichannel audio being loud.' Well, that just doesn't make sense. There's a volume know on all audio systems - you can turn it down.?.

You may suggest that Mr Murch is too dogmatic and stuck in old ways, old and with hurting eyes; each of which I'd argue - but I don't know him personally. What's for sure is that he has helped define the cinema going experience we love so much - and likely is directly responsible for many of the moments that caused you to like films to begin with - providing you do like cinema.

As far as audiences still going and you not hear complaints, well, people keep taking heroin, and I don't personally hear many complaints from them, either. And besides, I assume you've read a few of the comments before posting your hear - and so you must have seen some complaints.

Most everyone I know, when you break them out of their 'following along' mentality, tend to have complaints. Just about every person I spoke to about 'Avatar' said they loved it until I said I thought it was terrible. It hadn't occurred to them that it might not be a good movie - and most very quickly backed off. It had great colors - that's true. We all can agree on that.

As a number of Mr Murch's friends are currently messing around with 3D, I'm sure he realises that it's a creative tool. Problem is, when something is bad, there's only so much you can do. Maybe it's like menthol cigarettes. Cigarettes are flat out bad, but I guess you can add some flavor to it.

I contend that real cinema will not embrace 3D - only the corporations and those conditioned to follow them. And, in the case of Scorsese - someone I consider as neither - I contend that periodically he plays along with the studios so as to keep himself in the big budget game - which is where I pray he stays.

Best,
Matt

Alex | August 22, 2011 2:42 PM

@Paulo I disagree with you and you destroy your argument by bringing ageism into it. The fact is colour and sound added to a filmmaker's ability to tell a story. 3-D adds nothing - I've been asking the question for 3 years and no one has been able to tell me how the addition of 3-D adds anything beyond something cosmetic. (High def adds to the storytelling because it becomes easier to read data on the screen - signs, letters, costuming, etc - all aspects that might impact a story in some way). The audio comparison is silly, in my opinion because most filmgoers don't notice that anyway. For me, 3-D ruins the moviegoing experience to the point where the only films I find myself looking forward to being released now are art films put out by smart people who know their films will stand the test of time, whereas the 3-D films are not. I've been a James Bond fan for 35 years - and I'm faced with a scenario where I may for the first time not be able to go to the next Bond film because it's in 3-D. They are disenfranchising a huge segment of the filmgoing population by doing this.

Sgt. York | September 7, 2011 3:29 PM

"Who hasn't watched a great film and been totally absorbed in the moment. It's hard to see how 3D could improve that."

To back up this point, consider the last really good foreign film you watched. If the story grips you (to use Murch's phrasing) then you actually forget you're reading subtitles, and after awhile, you even begin to hear their voices almost talking in English. Despite the fact that you've spent the majority of 120 or so minutes reading text, you feel as though you've "experienced" the movie the same way you've experienced any good film.

3D is nothing more than a novelty. No one ever "forgets" they're watching a 3D film the way you can "forget" you're watching a foreign language movie, because you are asked to notice the visuals, as opposed to accept them for the sake of the story.

Ric | September 10, 2011 1:21 AM

I read the argument, looked at the salt shaker example presented as an impossible obstacle and shook my head going "Oh dear, more disinformation". For that image pair, shoot the background separately to the foreground (use chroma key), composite and compress the convergence and focus to within tolerable percentages.

The problem with stereographic 3D is that when is it technically flawed commentators that do not understand the process usually write off 3D because they think a better result is not possible. That's equivalent to going to a restaurant and having a bad experience and concluding that ALL restaurants are no good and never will be. "Case Closed"

Louis Barbarelli | September 12, 2011 12:26 PM

I respect both Roger Ebert and Walter Murch very much, but I think both are off base on this subject.

I'm not a scientist but it seems to me that Murch's point that evolution didn't prepare the human eye for cinematic 3D is a questionable one. Evolution didn't prepare us for 2D movies, either-- the brain having 24 separate images flashed at it every second. Yet the brain adapted, didn't it?

I think the main problems are practical: the glasses and the dimness. Both are fixable. Technology is moving rapidly on both fronts.

And Murch's argument that you don't need 3D because a good story makes you forget the 3D anyway is the same argument some critics used to make about sound and technicolor in days gone by. And I'll bet both Murch and Ebert will be the first to admit that the best movie music soundtrack is the kind you don't really notice during the movie. Just because something isn't "noticed" on one level of your consciousness, doesn't mean it doesn't enhance the film.

The whole argument against 3D is so vehement that it makes me suspicious. Why do some people seem to denounce 3D with almost religious fervor? Nobody is forcing them to watch it; 2D versions of 3D films are usually available. What gives? Leave it up to the public. If 3D isn't wanted, it will die all by itself.

As far as I'm concerned, case still open.


Tom | September 14, 2011 4:06 PM

It takes a bit to get use to. The way it works requires a dominate eye, just like some people are left handed, most are right, there is a reverse mode to accommodate people that are left eye dominate. 3D is only going to get better and cheaper. 3D isn't going anywhere except probably into the home of ROGER EBERT.

And new technology is often misused. When CDs first came out, in the rush to get discs to market, some bad ones were made. There a badly produced recordings on CDs, but there are also very good ones. Over time the movie producers will learn what works and what doesn't work for 3d.
I will agree that 3d is not the lowest common denominator as some people will probably never care for it and will demand 2d. But there will still be a huge 3d market and that market will pay more to see a 3d movie that a 2d movie. I wouldn't pay to see a 2d movie if a well done 3d version was a choice.

Dan Huby | November 27, 2011 5:21 PM

I'm not sure I agree with the points raised. Recent 3D films such as Avatar have addressed the convergence / focus issue by making most of the action happen at around the distance of the cinema screen, and rarely placing objects close to the viewer (which is normally reserved for effects such as the falling 'seeds' in Avatar, which are meant to be out of focus).

This technique is maintained for close ups which has the effect of making faces and objects look gigantic, but it does make it much more watchable than if they were kept life-sized and placed closer to the viewer.

Earlier 3D efforts, such as the Imax film "Space Station 3D", would regularly place objects very close to the viewer. I remember one particular scene where you are looking out from within a space suit and the hands of the suit are approximately where your own real hands would be - impressive, but also quite disconcerting and with severe focusing / convergence issues.

The new wave of 3D films have been much more subtle and therefore much more watchable in my opinion. I find that 3D has the effect of improving picture quality/resolution and adds realism. But it has been overhyped - and a good film will still be good in 2D.

lt | December 2, 2011 3:52 PM

"I'm at a basketball game, sitting next to the action, on the narrow side of the court. Sometimes the action is at the far side of the court, sometimes there is action near me. My eyes have to focus in and out, and be aware of action in other parts of my field of vision, despite lots of distractions."

You aren't understanding the problem at all. The problem occurs because unlike real life you are focusing in a different plane than is actually being simulated. You aren't shifting focus your are being lied to about the focal plane and the mind knows it.

ozan | December 28, 2011 6:59 AM

Eyes see things in 2d in real life. So it doesn't matter how far the tv plane is.. Brain makes it 3d. When I play game with 100% depth and a bit convergence, when I focus to the tip of my gun I see 2 enemy soldiers blurry, when I focus the enemy I see 2 gun tip in front of my nose.. just like in real life. So whole 3d isn't working idea is bullshit. It just need to be done more optimized for best result.. BTW playing games in 3d vision is much more realistic than 3d movies in 30% depth ...

3D isn't going anywhere. Its here to stay. :)

Taylor | February 17, 2012 8:56 AM

I can respect this reasoning as meaningfully valid as any argument against 3D as I've ever heard. However, it's still inadequate justification.

I live in rural Canada with a lake near my house. Twilight In the fall when the heat from the sun has warmed the clay insulated lake, you get steam rising as the temperature drops. It has this way of settling on a still night in varying degrees of density on the layers of the pond. You'll get three layers of moisture and three subsequent layers of reflectivity off the water. As light penetrates through the water, each layer reflects the surrounding landscape with higher degrees of refraction based on density.

You see the three layers of reflectivity will converge on the water level. The result is a mess of refracted dead light, where it's possible for you to focus on particular components of the reflected landscape but not the landscape as a whole. None-the-less, you are always converging on the water level. It's the same as 3D. It does exist in nature.

And by the same token. Human beings' persistence of vision has adapted radically in 100 years of cinema. In the early 20's we had 8-12 fps on most film, sometimes as low as 6. The human response rate, pooled from scientific data at the University of Ottawa in the 1980's indicated that, over a 10 year span, the human capacity for persistence of vision has changed. Since we've started watching film, our brains have learned to process incremental imagery at 5 times the rate. And you can't tell me in 600 million years of evolution we've readily experienced persistence of vision naturally.

We adapt to aberrant visual stimuli faster than any other kind. It's scientifically verifiable. Humans will adapt to stereoscopic convergence and focus within 25-50 years and it will facilitate the shift to glasses-less 3D.

Click for RogerEbert.com

The Webby Awards
Person of the Year

Best Blog: Natl. Soc. of Newspaper Columnists

One of the year's best blogs -- Time

Year's best blog: Am. Assn. of Sunday and Feature Editors

Roger Ebert

Ebert's latest books are "Life Itself: A Memoir," "The Great Movies III," "Roger Ebert's Movie Yearbook 2012." Volumes I and II of "The Great Movies" and "Awake in the Dark: The Best of Roger Ebert" can also be ordered via the links in the right column of RogerEbert.com

Search

About this Entry

This page contains a single entry by Roger Ebert published on January 23, 2011 7:57 PM.

Leading with my chin was the previous entry in this blog.

After 3D, here is the future of film is the next entry in this blog.

Find recent content on the main index or look in the archives to find all content.
